notes.text: Words like hardly, scarcely, and rarely should not be used with negative constructions. Thus, it is correct to say I can hardly wait but incorrect to say I can't hardly wait. This is because adverbs like hardly are treated as if they were negatives, and it is a grammatical rule of standard English that double negatives are not acceptable. Words like hardly behave as negatives in other respects as well, as for example in combining with terms such as any or at all, which normally occur only where a negative is present (thus, standard usage is I've got hardly any money, but not I've got any money). See also double negative

definitions: scarcely (used to qualify a statement by saying that it is true to an insignificant degree)

examples.text: the little house in which he lived was hardly bigger than a hut
a thing hardly bigger than a credit card

definitions: only a very short time before

examples.text: the party had hardly started when the police arrived
I nodded, hardly able to breath

definitions: no or not (suggesting surprise at or disagreement with a statement)
